Vulkan SDK for Windows Release Notes

Vulkan SDK 1.1.85.0 Release Notes

Version 1.1.85.0 for Windows
October 4, 2018

This SDK supports Vulkan API revision 1.1.85. The prior SDK supported Vulkan API revision 1.1.82.

Much of the documentation for this SDK is contained in the Getting Started Guide, found in the Documentation directory in this SDK and on the LunarXchange website.

Drivers: LunarG recommends updating Vulkan-capable hardware drivers to the latest recommended version from the hardware vendor. A list of Known Issues appears at the end of this document with more information.

Overview of new features in SDK 1.1.85.0

  • On September 19, 2018, NVIDIA released new Vulkan extensions to support their Turing architecture. These new extensions are supported and covered by Vulkan validation layers and the SPIR-V toolchain.
  • Since the release of SDK 1.1.82.1, the following extensions have been added to the Vulkan spec and may be supported by a Vulkan device. To query the extensions available to a given physical device, call vkEnumerateDeviceExtensionProperties() or contact the hardware vendor.
    VK_EXT_astc_decode_mode
    VK_EXT_inline_uniform_block
    VK_KHR_vulkan_memory_model
    VK_NV_compute_shader_derivatives
    VK_NV_corner_sampled_image
    VK_NV_fragment_shader_barycentric
    VK_NV_mesh_shader
    VK_NV_representative_fragment_test
    VK_NV_scissor_exclusive
    VK_NV_shader_image_footprint
    VK_NV_shading_rate_image
    VK_NVX_raytracing
  • VUID validation coverage documentation is now included in the LunarG Vulkan SDK. This documentation (validation_error_database.csv and an HTML version) has been updated to represent the validation layer VUID coverage status as of this 1.1.85.0 SDK. validation_error_database.csv can be found locally in the SDK Documentation directory once the SDK is installed on the system. A spreadsheet editor can be used to sort and view the data. Additionally, an HTML version of the validation error database can be found here.
  • Bug fixes (see the SDK Components section below)
  • Improved validation coverage

  • SPIR-V Specification version 1.3

Developer Notes

  • In the next Vulkan SDK release, cube and via will be renamed vkcube and vkvia respectively. SDK 1.1.85.0 will be the final Vulkan SDK to employ the names cube and via.
  • via has been updated to look for Implicit Layers installed along with drivers placed in the Windows Driver Store.
  • The standard Khronos validation layers have been migrated to use the canonical Vulkan VUID values, which are strings in the form of "VUID-vkCmdBlitImage-filter-00236". In doing so, the old integer-based enumerated values have been phased out and are no longer returned by log_msg() calls.
    • Developers keying on these returned values for their development should use the map in the vk_validation_error_messages.h file to obtain the matching Vulkan VUIDs when performing their updates. This file can be found in the the SDK in the VulkanSDK\<SDK version>\Source\layers\ directory and in the layers directory of the Vulkan-ValidationLayers GitHub repository.

Known Issues

  • Applications, such as vulkaninfo or via, may produce a warning to inform the user the VK_LAYER_RENDERDOC_Capture layer is using the deprecated vkGetDeviceProcAddr tag. This tag was deprecated starting with JSON file version 1.1.0. The presentation of this warning can manifest in a variety of ways. This issue has been reported to the RenderDoc team.
  • SDK applications might not appear in the Start Menu if another version of the SDK is currently installed on the system. This can be corrected by uninstalling all other versions of the SDK.
  • Prior to the August 3, 2018 Steam update, applications such as cube and cubepp could experience a crash in VkCreateSwapChainKHR() if the Steam Overlay Layer (VK_LAYER_VALVE_steam_overlay) was enabled. If this error occurs, first try updating the Steam client by clicking the "Steam" menu and selecting "Check for Steam Client Updates...". If the Steam client cannot be updated or the error persists, the behavior can be avoided by disabling the Steam Overlay Layer in one of the following ways:
    1. Set the DISABLE_VK_LAYER_VALVE_steam_overlay_1 environment variable equal to 1. This can be accomplished by editing the user environment variables under the Advanced System Properties menu or if a command prompt is utilized to execute the application, run the following command from the command prompt (Note: This change will only persist for a single command prompt session):
    set DISABLE_VK_LAYER_VALVE_steam_overlay_1=1
    1. Edit the Windows registry. To open the Windows registry, navigate to the Start Menu and either in the Run box or the Search box type regedit and press Enter. Navigate to Computer -> HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE_SOFTWARE -> SOFTWARE -> Khronos -> Vulkan -> ImplicitLayers. The SteamOverlayVulkanLayer64.json entry should be found here. Double click the file name and change the value in the "Value Data" box to 1. For 64-bit versions of Windows, an additional step must be performed by making the same change in the WOW6432Node directory. The registry entries found in the WOW6432Node directory are referenced when 32-bit programs are run on a 64-bit system. To make this change, navigate to Computer -> HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE_SOFTWARE -> SOFTWARE -> WOW6432Node -> Khronos -> Vulkan -> ImplicitLayers. For the SteamOverlayVulkanLayer.json entry, double-click the file name and change the value in the "Value Data" box to 1.
